statement:
First we define the function $$H(t) =
  \begin{cases}
    1 & \text{for } 0 \leq t < \tfrac{1}{2} \\
    -1 & \text{for } \tfrac{1}{2} \leq t \leq 1 \\
    0 & \text{otherwise.}
  \end{cases}$$ and the sequence of functions
$$H_n(t) = 2^{j/2}H(2^j t - k)$$ for $n=2^j+k$ where $j>0$ and
$0\leq k \leq 2^j$. We also set $H_0(t)=1$.

If $\{Z_n:0\leq n < \infty \}$ is a sequence of independent Gaussian
random variables with mean $0$ and variance $1$, then the series defined
by $$X_t = \sum^{\infty}_{n=0} \left(Z_n \int_0^t H_n(s)\;ds\right)$$
converges uniformly on $[0,1]$ with probability one. Moreover, the
process $\{X_t\}$ defined by the limit is a *Brownian motion* for
$0 \leq t \leq 1$.
